dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: So, you know, we're always talking about the next big financial crisis, right? And, uh, the conventional wisdom is usually, like, "Oh yeah, it'll happen again."
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So, you know, we're always talking about the next big financial crisis, right? And, uh, the conventional wisdom is usually, like, Oh yeah, it'll happen again.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, for sure. It feels like every, what, seven to ten years we're due for another one, especially with how quickly people forget the last time.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, for sure. It feels like every, what, seven to ten years we're due for another one, especially with how quickly people forget the last time.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The kind of full-blown systemic global financial crisis that erupted a decade ago is not like a typical septennial recession. The much lower frequency of systemic crises reflects two realities: policymakers respond with reforms to prevent their recurrence, and it normally takes investors, consumers, and politicians a long time to forget the last one.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly. But this article brings up an interesting point: what if the next one isn't like the last one? You know, the 2008 playbook might not work.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly. But this article brings up an interesting point: what if the next one isn't like the last one? You know, the two thousand eight playbook might not work.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: To be sure, if the next crisis is exactly like the last one, any policymaker can simply follow the playbook created in 2008, and the response probably will be at least as effective. But what if the next crisis is completely different...

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Oh, totally. Like, they mention a severe cyberattack, or, um, an unexpectedly rapid rise in global real interest rates. [overlaps] Which, uh...
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oh, totally. Like, they mention a severe cyberattack, or, um, an unexpectedly rapid rise in global real interest rates. Which, uh...
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: But what if the next crisis is completely different, resulting from say, a severe cyberattack, or an unexpectedly rapid rise in global real interest rates, which rocks fragile markets for high-risk debt?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: [overlaps] Yeah, which could really rock, like, fragile markets for high-risk debt. And then you have to ask, who's actually in charge?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, which could really rock, like, fragile markets for high-risk debt. And then you have to ask, who's actually in charge?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: ...an unexpectedly rapid rise in global real interest rates, which rocks fragile markets for high-risk debt?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Right? The article gives a lot of credit to Jay Powell and the Fed, saying they're "first-rate." But then they question, uh, the wider administration.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right? The article gives a lot of credit to Jay Powell and the Fed, saying they're first-rate. But then they question, uh, the wider administration.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: US Federal Reserve chair Jay Powell and his team are first-rate, but who will be the other adults in the room if an externally generated financial crisis threatens?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, it's like, who are the other adults in the room, right? And then you look at Europe, and it's, um, arguably even worse.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, it's like, who are the other adults in the room, right? And then you look at Europe, and it's, um, arguably even worse.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Europe has issues that are similar, or worse.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Oh, absolutely. With, like, populism fueling deep divisions, and, uh, the Brexit situation in the UK. It's a mess.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oh, absolutely. With, like, populism fueling deep divisions, and, uh, the Brexit situation in the U K. It's a mess.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: With populism fueling deep distrust and divisions, financial resilience is almost certainly far lower than it was a decade ago. Just look at the United Kingdom, the other major global financial center, where the political elite have taken the country to the edge of the Brexit cliff.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, they even say the UK has "very bad staff" in its Treasury and central bank, which is, like, a pretty harsh assessment.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, they even say the U K has very bad staff in its Treasury and central bank, which is, like, a pretty harsh assessment.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The UK is fortunate to have very good staff in its Treasury as well as its central bank, but even the brightest boffins can do only so much if politicians dont give them cover.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: It is! And then they throw in this, uh, idea that the next big financial crisis might be 20 to 40 years away. I mean, come on.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: It is! And then they throw in this, uh, idea that the next big financial crisis might be twenty to forty years away. I mean, come on.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: But wont it be another 20-40 years before the next big financial crisis, leaving plenty of time to get ready? One hopes so, but it is far from certain.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: [chuckles] I know, right? That sounds incredibly optimistic. Especially when they also say "it is very certain" a crisis *will* come.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: I know, right? That sounds incredibly optimistic. Especially when they also say it is very certain a crisis will come.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: But wont it be another 20-40 years before the next big financial crisis, leaving plenty of time to get ready? One hopes so, but it is far from certain.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, it's a bit contradictory. And, uh, what about all the reforms since 2008? Are we actually safer?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, it's a bit contradictory. And, uh, what about all the reforms since two thousand eight? Are we actually safer?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Well, the article argues that regulators are wrong to say there have been improvements. They suggest that risks have just, like, migrated.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Well, the article argues that regulators are wrong to say there have been improvements. They suggest that risks have just, like, migrated.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Policymakers are right to say there have been improvements in the system since 2008. But the piecemeal reforms that have been enacted fall far short of what is most necessary...

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, to the less regulated shadow financial system, which is, um, pretty concerning. It's not fixed, it's just out of sight.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, to the less regulated shadow financial system, which is, um, pretty concerning. It's not fixed, it's just out of sight.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: ...it is likely that major sources of risk have simply migrated to the less regulated shadow financial system.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: So, all these, uh, comprehensive reforms haven't really done the most necessary thing, which is requiring banks to raise more funding through equity.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So, all these, uh, comprehensive reforms haven't really done the most necessary thing, which is requiring banks to raise more funding through equity.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: But the piecemeal reforms that have been enacted fall far short of what is most necessary: requiring banks to raise a larger share of their funding through equity issuance...

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Nope. And, uh, despite the article ending on this note about an "inexorably shrinking financial system," it feels like we're still in a precarious spot.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Nope. And, uh, despite the article ending on this note about an inexorably shrinking financial system, it feels like we're still in a precarious spot.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Unfortunately, an inexorably growing financial system, combined with an increasingly toxic political environment, means that the next major financial crisis may come sooner than you think.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: It does. It's like, are we really going to wait 20-40 years, or, uh, is the next completely different crisis right around the corner?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: It does. It's like, are we really going to wait twenty to forty years, or, uh, is the next completely different crisis right around the corner?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly. And who's gonna be there to deal with it, right?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly. And who's gonna be there to deal with it, right?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Good question for another day, maybe!
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Good question for another day, maybe!
